channel.title: Comments on: Spatial Data From Your iPhone
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: PaurbirrerM
item.dc:creator: PaurbirrerM
item.description: I find myself coming to your blog more and more often to the point where my visits are almost daily now!<br />
item.content:encoded: I find myself coming to your blog more and more often to the point where my visits are almost daily now!

item.title: By: Brian Davis
item.dc:creator: Brian Davis
item.content:encoded:
@cbetancourt: I haven’t tried openheatmap.com yet, but I’ll take a look at that, thanks.

I believe you are correct with the triangulation idea. I haven’t seen anything in terms of proof as to how it’s being done though. There were some places that were logged that I haven’t visited. My other guess is that the phone might have been through these places during shipping from the manufacturer to the store(s).

item.title: By: Claude
item.dc:creator: Claude
item.content:encoded:
@brian78: I think that’s due the fact the phone is really using triangulation to determine its general location. The phone stores the cell tower locations.

Have you tried to visualize the data with something like openheatmap.com? You’ll see there are places that you haven’t visited, but your phone says you have.

item.title: By: Claude Betancourt
item.dc:creator: Claude Betancourt
item.content:encoded:
SQLDenis, I thought you had read my short post on this. Verizon customers data is stored in the CDMACellLocation table.

http://bit.ly/eyR1jR

item.title: By: Brian Davis
item.dc:creator: Brian Davis
item.content:encoded:
Denis – Thanks for info on the Verizon iPhone.

Another thing I’ve found is that the TimeStamp field can have some wierd data at times. There were a few entries in mine that had the same TimeStamp but were a good distance apart. I haven’t found a good explaination for this yet.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Just as a FYI for those people with a Verizon iPhone who would like to run this code, you would use the <strong>CdmaCellCollection </strong>file
item.content:encoded: Just as a FYI for those people with a Verizon iPhone who would like to run this code, you would use the CdmaCellCollection file
